dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: People think the US is the ultimate financial safe haven, but actually, history shows capital can flee from it in a crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: People think the U S is the ultimate financial safe haven, but actually, history shows capital can flee from it in a crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No one doubted that the US was the epicenter of the global financial crisis. But rather than flee the US, capital actually flooded into it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like that 2008 example—net sales of US assets hit a half-trillion dollars in just three months. That's a massive outflow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like that two thousand eight example-net sales of U S assets hit a half-trillion dollars in just three months. That's a massive outflow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the last three months of 2008, net purchases of US assets reached a half-trillion dollars three times more than that of the preceding nine months combined.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and it wasn't just because banks needed yen or something. A lot of it was, uh, sheer panic—investors saw the US as the riskiest bet back then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and it wasn't just because banks needed yen or something. A lot of it was, uh, sheer panic-investors saw the U S as the riskiest bet back then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At a time when nobody knew how bad things might get, the US was widely seen as the safest bet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then Obama came in and really shifted that perception. He spent his first two years rebuilding international trust and practicing fiscal responsibility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then Obama came in and really shifted that perception. He spent his first two years rebuilding international trust and practicing fiscal responsibility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this was before the arrival US President Donald Trump, who has managed to undermine confidence in the dollar to an unprecedented degree. In addition to abandoning any notion of fiscal responsibility, Trump has spent his first two years in office attacking international institutions and picking fights with US allies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But even before Obama, there was that Moodys upgrade in 2011, which boosted confidence in mortgage-backed securities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But even before Obama, there was that Moodys upgrade in twenty eleven, which boosted confidence in mortgage-backed securities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, even before Trump, confidence in the dollar suffered a blow in 2011, when Standard & Poors downgraded Treasury securities by one notch in response to a near-shutdown of the US government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, though that was partly due to an agreement with Congress on the debt ceiling, which feels almost ironic now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, though that was partly due to an agreement with Congress on the debt ceiling, which feels almost ironic now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That episode was triggered by a standoff between then-President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans over a routine proposal to raise the federal debt ceiling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And today, investors worry even less about US credit, especially since the government hasn't shut down since 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And today, investors worry even less about U S credit, especially since the government hasn't shut down since twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, however, investors have even more reason to worry about the US governments credit rating. In 2018 alone, the US government was shut down three times, and it remains in a partial shutdown to this day, owing to Trumps demand for funds to build a big, beautiful wall on the border with Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But where does that leave people looking for alternatives? The yuan seems logical, but China's capital markets are still tiny compared to the US.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But where does that leave people looking for alternatives? The yuan seems logical, but China's capital markets are still tiny compared to the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And then there is China, with the worlds third-largest national market for public debt. Certainly, the supply of assets in China is ample.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Europe's not exactly stable either—economic stagnation in the UK, banking risks in Switzerland…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Europe's not exactly stable either-economic stagnation in the U K, banking risks in Switzerland...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economic growth is slowing, not least in Germany, and the risk of a banking crisis in Italy the eurozones fourth-largest economy looms on the horizon. Worse still is the uncertainty over Brexit, which could prove highly disruptive if the United Kingdom crashes out of the European Union without a divorce agreement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus Brexit uncertainty hanging over everything. Britain could be a risky haven until that's resolved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus Brexit uncertainty hanging over everything. Britain could be a risky haven until that's resolved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, Britain, too, can be ruled out as a safe haven, at least until the Brexit fiasco is resolved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: What about Japan? Its government debt is less than 10% of GDP, which sounds great, but the market's super unstable because foreign creditors hold so much of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What about Japan? Its government debt is less than ten percent of G D P, which sounds great, but the market's super unstable because foreign creditors hold so much of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The question for portfolio managers, though, is whether it is really safe to invest in a country where government debt exceeds 230% of GDP. Admittedly, the market for Japanese government debt is more stable than most, owing to the fact that much of it is held by domestic savers (which is to say, it is safely tucked under the mattress).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And China's private equity market is huge, but its assets are scarce and regulation is loose—hardly a safe bet for global investors yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And China's private equity market is huge, but its assets are scarce and regulation is loose-hardly a safe bet for global investors yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Certainly, the supply of assets in China is ample. But the Chinese market is so tightly controlled that it is essentially the opposite of a safe haven.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So really, despite its flaws, the US dollar remains the default. Investors might get jumpy at any sign of trouble, but for now, volatility is low.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So really, despite its flaws, the U S dollar remains the default. Investors might get jumpy at any sign of trouble, but for now, volatility is low.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They will be inclined to move funds at the slightest sign of danger, which will add substantially to market volatility. Todays rough patch is probably here to stay.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though as Benjamin J. Cohen points out, this smooth patch probably won't last forever. Rival currencies and shifting trust could change things fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though as Benjamin J. Cohen points out, this smooth patch probably won't last forever. Rival currencies and shifting trust could change things fast.
